poll-gallery.question: What question would you ask the artist about this painting if you had the chance?
choices: What‚Äôs in the frame behind them?
Does their hand positioning have meaning?
poll-gallery.followup: Kerry James Marshall, is a living artist who is best known for portraits such as this one. He draws from the canon and history of art, specifically painting, as references for pose and composition.

poll-lices.question: Where do you go to find time alone?
poll-lices.followup: Paul Signac used lots of painted dots to create this image. This technique is called pointillism and is part of the Impressionist movement. Signac and other impressionists were interested in how color could show different times of day and create different moods.

poll-prince.question: What do you think this figure is looking at on their phone?
poll-prince.followup: This sculpture is the work of Nicole Eisenman, who draws on sources ranging from the iconography of classical myths to popular culture.

poll-iceberg.question: What does this painting make you think of?
choices: The impact humans have on nature.
poll-iceberg.followup: The artist, Frederic Church, first sketched icebergs on a perilous trip to Newfoundland and Labrador in 1859 following the disappearance of a ship and its crew in the far north while searching for the Northwest Passage.

poll-brillo.question: Which one of these ordinary household items could inspire you to make art?
poll-brillo.followup: In the mid-1960s Andy Warhol‚Äôs caused controversy with his ‚ÄôBrillo Box‚Äô sculptures. In reference to his boxes, Warhol later said that he ‚Äôwanted something ordinary,‚Äô and it was this mundane, commercial subject matter that infuriated the critics.

faq.question: How do I scan a code?
Can you tell me a joke?

schedule.description: Grab a friend, get a drink at the cash bar, and enjoy a night out!
schedule.details: For a more social experience, we are open until 10 p.m. and offer half-price museum admission and a cash bar beginning at 5 p.m.

schedule.description: To register, call 412.622.3314 or email membership@carnegiemuseums.org.

schedule.event: Member Tour: The Secret Language of Art
schedule.description: To register, call 412.622.3314 or email membership@carnegiemuseums.org.

schedule.event: Grand Opening of PPG Science Pavilion‚Ñ¢ and The Art of the Brick
schedule.description: Kick off Summer Adventure with the highly-anticipated opening of the PPG Science Pavilion. A limited number of free tickets to The Art of the Brick will be available for members as well as activities celebrating the brand-new learning spaces!
Visitors can explore a topic in-depth through hands-on activities, experiments, demonstrations, discussions with museum experts, family-friendly activities, and more.
Party in the Sculpture Court with girlFx.

schedule.event: Member Tour: Adman: Warhol Before Pop
schedule.description: To register, call 412.622.3314 or email membership@carnegiemuseums.org.

Celebrate CMOA‚Äôs Japanese print exhibition, Hiroshige‚Äôs T√¥kaid√¥ Road, with this Japanese Tanabata Festival for all ages! Add your wishes to our outdoor bamboo garden, see and make amazing prints, sample foods, and listen to traditional music.

In conjunction with the exhibition Adman: Warhol Before Pop, The Warhol and Eons Fashion Antique host a night of cocktails, music, and 1950s fashion at Window Dressing: An Evening of Fashion. Live models showcasing items from Richard Parsakian‚Äôs archive will bring to life works from Adman. The cash bar will feature craft drinks inspired by Andy Warhol‚Äôs mother, Julia Warhola.
To register, call 412.622.3314 or email membership@carnegiemuseums.org.

schedule.event: Member Tour: Fresh Air, Public Art
schedule.description: To register, call 412.622.3314 or email membership@carnegiemuseums.org.
Experience Carnegie paleontologist Matt Lamanna‚Äôs arctic trek in Expedition Antarctica and enjoy a sweet treat afterward!
Celebrate the opening of Crossroads, the new installation of our postwar contemporary collection.
Visitors can explore a topic in-depth through hands-on activities, experiments, demonstrations, discussions with museum experts, family-friendly activities, and more.
Grab a friend, get a drink at the cash bar, and enjoy a night out!

Celebrate the Andy Warhol‚Äôs 90th birthday with family-friendly activities throughout the museum. Join us for special gallery activities, hands-on artmaking, and a behind-the-scenes look at The Warhol‚Äôs extensive and unusual archives.

The second annual Powdermill Pollinator Festival is free and open to the public, and will include food, garden tours, and sales of honey and bee products, as well as a large plant sale which will highlight native plants that attract pollinators.
schedule.details: This event takes place at Powdermill Nature Reserve in Rector, PA

schedule.description: To register, call 412.622.3314 or email membership@carnegiemuseums.org.

schedule.event: Member Tour: Contemporary Galleries (+ Carry on the Conversation)
schedule.description: To register, call 412.622.3314 or email membership@carnegiemuseums.org.
City of Play and slowdanger present an evening of interactions and immersive adventures.
Visitors can explore a topic in-depth through hands-on activities, experiments, demonstrations, discussions with museum experts, family-friendly activities, and more.

End your summer adventure with a bang! Spend an evening testing the knowledge you acquired from your time at the museums this summer. Bring your stamped Summer Adventure Map for the chance to win prizes. Each stamp is another chance to win gift certificates, membership renewal, Carnegie Cash, and more in the drawing.
This tour traces Warhol‚Äôs romantic relationships and queer identity against the backdrop of the historical gay rights movement in the United States.
schedule.details: Tours meet on the seventh floor.
schedule.when: Last Saturday of each month, Saturdays and Sunday in June

schedule.event: Tours Truly: Free Daily Collection Tour
schedule.description: Learn about the works in CMOA‚Äôs collection from our trained docents. Every tour is unique!
Meet the live animals that call Carnegie Museum of Natural History home at Live Animal Encounters.

Gallery talks led by museum staff have a thematic focus around a series of Warhol artworks or one of Warhol‚Äôs artistic processes. These 30-minute talks provide time for visitors to present insights and ask questions.
schedule.details: Tours meet on the museum‚Äôs seventh floor.

schedule.description: Shows are included with general admission for visitors to the Science Center.
schedule.details: Check the calendar for today‚Äôs show schedule.
schedule.when: Check the calendar for today‚Äôs show schedule

schedule.description: Join a crew of fellow humans for a weekly, rejuvenating yoga session set in Pittsburgh‚Äôs most beautiful spaces!
schedule.details: All classes are drop-in; no online pre-registration is available.

stamps.name: PPG Grand Opening and Art of The Brick

scan.followup: üçî Thanks for inviting me to lunch. Want to sprinkle some trivia on that?
üöó Thanks for the ride! Want to try out some trivia?
üöó Thanks for the ride! Want to try out some trivia?

trivia-railroad.text: The Miniature Railroad and Village¬Æ was displayed for the first time ever in ____ by its creator Charles Bowdish.
trivia-railroad.followup: After 1919, the display grew until it occupied most of the second floor of the Bowdish home.

trivia-railroad.text: Where else did the Miniature Railroad and Village¬Æ live before moving to Carnegie Science Center?
trivia-railroad.followup: The Miniature Railroad and Village¬Æ was moved to the Science Center in 1992.

trivia-railroad.text: An earlier name for Mt. Washington in Pittsburgh, PA was _______.
trivia-railroad.followup: The leading coal producers in the United States mined the seam.

trivia-railroad.text: What is the name of this house, designed by renowned architect Frank Lloyd Wright?
trivia-railroad.followup: Fallingwater is located southeast of Pittsburgh, just over an hour away.

trivia-railroad.text: The spectators in the model of Forbes Field are made out of ________?
trivia-railroad.followup: The real Forbes Field took only four months to build out of steel and concrete, but the model took over a year to complete.

trivia-railroad.text: An object with an actual length of 10 ft, would be how long in this exhibit?
trivia-railroad.followup: The Miniature Railroad and Village¬Æ is built by the ‚ÄôO‚Äô Scale, where 1 foot is scaled down to 1/4 inch.

trivia-sports.text: Which of the following materials is used to make athletic tracks?
trivia-sports.followup: Enzymes can transform plant oils into a gel that will harden into a track that you can run on!

trivia-sports.text: _________ is a muscle‚Äôs ability to keep up a repeated force.
trivia-sports.followup: Many athletes train for both strength and endurance.

trivia-sports.text: A good hockey goalie has a reaction time that is ___% faster than an average person‚Äôs.
trivia-sports.followup: An average person has a reaction time of about .2 seconds. A hockey goalie is faster at .15 seconds-- those milliseconds count!

trivia-sports.text: Participating in sports helps keep your heart healthy. How many chambers are in a mammal‚Äôs heart?
trivia-sports.followup: Birds also have four chambers in their hearts.

trivia-sports.text: Isaac Newton‚Äôs Second Law of Motion: Force is Mass x ________?
trivia-sports.followup: When you swing a bat, it accelerates to maximum speed. That acceleration depends on the force you apply to the bat and the mass of the bat.

trivia-foodart.text: Andy Warhol made many artworks around food. Which of the following foods did Andy Warhol claim to eat every day for 20 years?
trivia-foodart.followup: Andy marveled that the soup always tasted the same, whether consumed by prince or pauper.

trivia-foodart.text: This machine was designed to make which beverage?
trivia-foodart.followup: In the early 17th century, the vessels used for serving tea became more inventive.

trivia-foodart.text: A model of which Pittsburgh restaurant was added to the Miniature Railroad and Village¬Æ at Carnegie Science Center in 2017?
trivia-foodart.followup: Updates are made to the Miniature Railroad and Village¬Æ each fall, just in time for the holidays!

trivia-foodart.text: Pictured here is a painting by Albert Francis King. He used a technique known as trompe l‚Äôoeil, which means ____________.
trivia-foodart.followup: Trompe l‚Äôoeil painters often selected household objects as subjects.

trivia-foodart.text: Which type of clay is this plate made from?
trivia-foodart.followup: These are the three main types of clay, often used to make tableware and dishes.

trivia-robots.text: What year was the term ‚Äúrobot‚Äù invented?
trivia-robots.followup: It was used in a play entitled R.U.R. by the Czech writer Karel ƒåapek.

trivia-robots.text: The device at the end of a robotic arm is called a(n) __________.
trivia-robots.followup: The form and function of an end effector can vary, depending on the purpose of the robot.

trivia-robots.text: What kind of sensors do robots use to detect their distance from an object?
trivia-robots.followup: These sonic range finders bounce sound off an object and measure the time it takes the sound to return to the sensor.

trivia-robots.text: The first robot to be used in industry was used by which automobile company?
trivia-robots.followup: In 1961, it was Devol and Engelberger‚Äôs UNIMATE.

trivia-robots.text: What is the name of this robot, who was introduced in the class sci-fi film ‚ÄúMetropolis‚Äù?
trivia-robots.followup: Maria was one of the first robotic icons of science fiction!

trivia-robots.text: What was a robot like Hoops, the basketball robot, originally used for?
trivia-robots.followup: Hoops nails free-throws with 98% accuracy and has been fascinating Science Center visitors for years.

trivia-foodscience.text: The digestive system begins in the __________.
trivia-foodscience.followup: Saliva is important for digestion; humans make about a liter of it each day.

trivia-foodscience.text: Stegosaurus had a brain that was the size of  _______________.
trivia-foodscience.followup: Compared to the size of its body (which is comparable to an elephant‚Äôs), Stegosaurus had a tiny brain.

trivia-foodscience.text: Most of food‚Äôs flavor comes from our sense of _______.
trivia-foodscience.followup: We can identify about 10,000 scents but only five basic tastes: sour, sweet, bitter, salty, and umami.

trivia-foodscience.text: The first cooked meal in space was ________.
trivia-foodscience.followup: It was cooked in a lemon garlic ginger marinade and eaten from a bag.

trivia-foodscience.text: The growth in popularity of which superfood has had a negative effect on monarch butterfly populations?
trivia-foodscience.followup: Avocado farmers are clearing land, removing a vital buffer of trees that helps stabilize the climate of the butterflies‚Äô winter retreat.

trivia-warholearly.text: Andy Warhol‚Äôs parents were from modern-day
trivia-warholearly.followup: Andrej and Julia Warhola were Carpatho-Rusyns who immigrated from what is now eastern Slovakia in the 1920s.

trivia-warholearly.text: As a child, Andy Warhol had a rare illness that often kept him bed-ridden. What was it?
trivia-warholearly.followup: The disease caused involuntary movement, but being bed-ridden was a formative time for Warhol: He would listen to the radio, draw, and collect pictures of movie stars.

trivia-warholearly.text: Warhol attended college at Carnegie Tech (now Carnegie Mellon University). How did he afford it?
trivia-warholearly.followup: Warhol‚Äôs father Andrej recognized his son‚Äôs talent early and saved bonds for his education.
Warhol designed the windows of Joseph Horne‚Äôs in downtown Pittsburgh.

trivia-warholearly.text: Warhol began his career in New York as a(n) _______.
trivia-warholearly.followup: His first commercial work appeared in a 1949 issue of Glamour magazine, in which he illustrated a story called ‚ÄúWhat is Success?‚Äù

trivia-warholart.followup: Warhol‚Äôs love for flowers was reflected in his countless Flowers prints.

trivia-warholart.text: Warhol‚Äôs artistic process took off with this technique.
trivia-warholart.followup: This time-saving technique combined drawing with printmaking and allowed Warhol to recreate images quickly, thus outpacing his competition.

trivia-warholart.text: Warhol started experimenting with film in the early 1960s. What is his longest film?
trivia-warholart.followup: The film Empire, showing the Empire State Building, clocks in at 8 hours and 5 minutes.

trivia-warholart.text: Who is the subject of the longest print at The Andy Warhol Museums?
trivia-warholart.followup: Warhol made 11 prints of Elvis Presley on a single canvas, intending to cut it into strips and sell each print separately.

trivia-warholart.text: Warhol loved to collect things. His most famous collection is ______.
trivia-warholart.followup: Warhol filled 610 cardboard Time Capsules with memorabilia from daily life: receipts, telegrams, medicine, and even a pizza!
In the Factory, the walls were painted silver and celebrities streamed in and out.

trivia-wearenature.text: What is the name of the newly proposed geological time period, defined by humans‚Äô effect on the environment?
trivia-wearenature.followup: This is the first time in recorded history that humans are impacting the earth as strongly as natural forces like asteroids, volcanic eruptions, or ice age global cooling.

trivia-wearenature.text: What is the name of this animal, which has been documented in every county in Pennsylvania?
trivia-wearenature.followup: Coyotes can live almost anywhere that humans do but are so secretive that we rarely see them.

trivia-wearenature.text: Which non-native species is flourishing in Everglades National Park in Florida?
trivia-wearenature.followup: Through humans releasing pets into the wild, Burmese pythons were brought to the Everglades. With no natural predators, they pose a threat to the balance of the ecosystem, already causing the disappearance of some small mammals in the Everglades.

trivia-wearenature.text: River otters no longer live in Pennsylvania waterways due to pollution, habitat destruction, and overhunting.
trivia-wearenature.followup: They almost disappeared from PA in the early 20th century. Following decades of work to clean our rivers, otters were reintroduced in 1982. Thanks to legal protection and improved habitat quality, their population has grown.

trivia-wearenature.text: Worldwide, humans buy one million plastic bottles every __________.
trivia-wearenature.followup: Of those bottles, 91% are thrown in the trash‚Äîmany of them finding their way into the oceans.

trivia-wearenature.text: Which of these critically endangered species is the most illegally trafficked animal in the world?
trivia-wearenature.followup: Pangolin populations have suffered from illegal trafficking due to unfounded beliefs that their ground-up scales can cure diseases.

trivia-flowers.followup: Powdermill Nature Reserve is Carnegie Museum of Natural History‚Äôs environmental research facility in Rector, PA. To see more great photos, follow Powdermill on Facebook!

trivia-birds.followup: Powdermill Nature Reserve is Carnegie Museum of Natural History‚Äôs environmental research facility in Rector, PA. These photos were taken by scientists at Powdermill Avian Research Center. To see more great photos, follow Powdermill on Facebook!

trivia-impressionism.text: When and where did the art movement known as Impressionism originate?
trivia-impressionism.followup: Impressionism revolutionized attitudes about painting methods, subject matter, and the art market.

trivia-impressionism.text: Impressionists never painted the same subject twice.
trivia-impressionism.followup: Impressionists often returned to the same subject repeatedly in order to study and capture the fleeting and constantly changing effects of light, weather, and social life.

trivia-impressionism.text: Impressionist Pierre-Auguste Renoir was included in how many Carnegie Internationals?
trivia-impressionism.followup: The Carnegie International is the longest-running survey of global contemporary art in North America. Many Impressionists were represented in the early years of the Carnegie International.

trivia-impressionism.text: What is the name for the painting technique of using small dots of bright, often contrasting colors, pictured here?
trivia-impressionism.followup: These marks were thought to vibrate or blend in the viewer‚Äôs eye to create a more subtle perception.

trivia-impressionism.text: Which painter created this work of art titled ‚ÄôWheat Fields after the Rain (The Plain of Auvers)‚Äô?
trivia-impressionism.followup: This is one of the very last paintings Vincent van Gogh ever made, painted just days before his death.

trivia-design.text: Deriving forms and decorative motifs from nature is known as ____________.
trivia-design.followup: Designers at the turn of the 20th century emphasized utility and beauty of form in the face of modern industrial production.

trivia-design.text: The Rococo style in decorative arts evolved from the formal, grandiose _________ style.
trivia-design.followup: The Rococo style is characterized by asymmetrical compositions of sensuous S- and C-shaped curves and the use of naturalistic motifs, such as rocks, shells, and foliage.

trivia-design.text: The swelling, curved lower section of this furniture is described as ____________, a term derived from a French word that means ‚Äúto bulge‚Äù.
trivia-design.followup: The time-consuming, labor-intensive process required to produce curved elements added to the cost of objects.

trivia-design.text: What is the name for the process of returning objects to their original historic form?
trivia-design.followup: The materials used in a restoration are scientifically tested for their stability and reversibility.

trivia-design.text: Carnegie Museum of Art has an especially notable collection of which decorative item?
trivia-design.followup: For centuries, artists have been stretching the boundaries of the chair form. The chairs displayed at the museum celebrate the diversity, beauty, and innovation of chair design from the late 17th century to the present.

trivia-dinos.text: What kind of dinosaur is ‚ÄúDippy,‚Äù who appears in Carnegie Museum of Natural History‚Äôs logo?
trivia-dinos.followup: In 1901, paleontologists realized they had discovered a new species of dinosaur and named it Diplodocus carnegii to recognize Andrew Carnegie‚Äôs support.

trivia-dinos.text: What was the first period of the Mesozoic Era?
Which of the following dinosaurs was a carnivore?
trivia-dinos.followup: Most carnivorous dinosaurs had sharp, pointed, blade-like teeth which were serrated like steak knives for cutting through meat.
Like other reptiles, dinosaurs laid eggs.
The horns of these dinosaurs were made of a material that does not typically fossilize. This is comparable to today‚Äôs rhinos, which have horns composed of keratin.

trivia-dinos.text: Where did Carnegie paleontologist Earl Douglass discover the first dinosaur fossils for the museum?
trivia-dinos.followup: Over 350 tons of spectacular fossil material were unearthed at Carnegie Quarry--the greatest deposit of Jurassic dinosaur bones ever discovered.

trivia-mineralsgems.text: The presence of which element can cause a mineral to appear blue or green?
trivia-mineralsgems.followup: Copper-bearing minerals include Azurite and Malachite, pictured above.

trivia-mineralsgems.text: Luster refers to how a mineral reflects light. Which of the following is NOT a way to describe luster?
trivia-mineralsgems.followup: Other forms of luster include pearly, dull, waxy, earthy, and silky.

trivia-mineralsgems.text: Basalt is which of the three main types of rock?
trivia-mineralsgems.followup: Igneous rocks are created when molten rock cools and crystallizes.

trivia-mineralsgems.text: The science of rocks is called _____?
trivia-mineralsgems.followup: Rocks are naturally occuring assemblages of two or more minerals. Rocks constitute an essential part of the Earth‚Äôs crust.

trivia-mineralsgems.text: Which instrument is used to detect radiation in minerals like uraninite?
trivia-mineralsgems.followup: A geiger counter is a useful tool for prospectors searching for uranium ore in Earth‚Äôs core.

trivia-mineralsgems.text: Gemstone quality is judged by the 4 C‚Äôs. Which of the following is NOT a C used to judge gem quality?
trivia-mineralsgems.followup: The 4 C‚Äôs are cut, clarity, color, and carat.

trivia-architecture.text: The Hall of Architecture contains casts of many famous buildings. What material are these copies made of?
trivia-architecture.followup: Plaster casting allowed masterpieces of sculpture and architecture to be brought to Pittsburgh, for everyone to experience at full scale.

trivia-architecture.text: This intricate cast comes from the doors on the Cathedral of St. Pierre in France. What are the original doors made of?
trivia-architecture.followup: Many of the plaster sculptures in the collection have been painted to give a warm, antique appearance that resembles the original building materials.

trivia-architecture.text: Andrew Carnegie wanted the walls in the Hall of Architecture painted purple, because it is a color associated with royalty.
trivia-architecture.followup: The walls were painted purple in 2013, as a part of the installation by artist Gabriel Sierra for the 2013 Carnegie International.

trivia-architecture.text: Approximately how many packing cases were required to move the pieces of this cast of the French Benedictine Abbey Church of St. Gilles from France to Pittsburgh?
trivia-architecture.followup: This cast was made in its entirety for Carnegie Museums and it is now the largest cast in the world. Cast and delivered in pieces, it had to be reassembled in the space, taking more than 18 months to complete.

trivia-architecture.text: The collection of architectural casts at Carnegie Museum of Art is the largest in the world.
trivia-architecture.followup: This collection is the third largest in the world, but the largest in the Americas. While most other collections have been either dispersed or destroyed, Carnegie Museum of Art‚Äôs collection has endured as an exhibition of world-class significance.
